description.en: The course starts by discussing the mission of International Relations as a discipline driven by specific practical and theoretical concerns, followed by a short introduction into the evolution of the discipline. The second, and main, part of the course includes a series of lectures and seminars which focus on the key formative concepts, such as sovereignty, anarchy and governance, agency, structure and the state, international system and international society, power, security, war and peace, conflict and cooperation, norms and identity, the role of the individual. The concepts are introduced through some of the classical texts that have shaped the discipline over decades; as a rule, each concept is introduced both from the rationalist and the constructivist perspective, and where possible, also through the prism of empirical issues. The concluding part of the course sums it up by linking the problematic of IR with the notion of modernity and asking whether today's practice of world politics is evolving beyond modernity or back to pre-modern times.
description.et: Kursuse alguses sõnastatakse rahvusvaheliste suhete kui teadusharu definitsioon konkreetsetest praktilistest ja teoreetilistest vaatepunktidest lähtuvalt. Järgmine ning suurem osa kursusest keskendub põhimõistetele nagu süveräänsus, anarhia, valitsemine, toimija- ja struktuurikesksus, rahvusvaheline süsteem, võim, julgeolek, sõda ja rahu, konflikt ja koostöö, normid ja identiteet jt. Mõistet tutvustatakse klassikaliste tekstide kaudu ning reeglina nii ratsionalistlikust kui konstruktivistlikust perspektiivist. Kursus lõpeb aruteluga sellest, kuhupoole liigub tänapäeva maailma poliitika.

objectives.en: This course introduces the students to the current state of IR as a discipline. It discusses key practical and theoretical concerns that define the discipline, main theoretical debates, and key concepts that organise the disciplinary field.
objectives.et: Kursus käsitleb rahvusvaheliste suhete teadusdistsipliini tänast seisu, analüüsides peamisi teoreetilisi ja praktilisi murekohti, peamisi teoreetilisi seisukohti ja teadusharu põhimõisteid.

learning_outcomes.en: Upon completing the course, the students will be able to:
1) understand the disciplinary logic of IR and its evolution since the beginning of the twentieth century;
learning_outcomes.et: 1) teab rahvusvaheliste suhete kui teadusharu olemust ning ajaloolist arengut;

learning_outcomes.en: 2) understand the key dividing lines between the rationalist and constructivist approaches in contemporary IR;
learning_outcomes.et: 2) teab põhilisi murdejooni ratsionalistlike ja konstruktivistlike lähenemiste vahel kaasaegses rahvusvaheliste suhete teooriates;

learning_outcomes.en: 3) understand how and why IR theories differ in their approach to the key concepts that shape the disciplinary field;
learning_outcomes.et: 3) teab, kuidas ja miks rahvusvaheliste suhete teooriad erinevad oma vaadetes teadusharu põhimõistetele;
4) on parandanud oma kriitilise lugemise oskust;

learning_outcomes.en: 5) enhance their ability to use scholarly concepts in speech and in writing.
learning_outcomes.et: 5) oskab õigesti kasutada teadusmõisteid nii kõnes kui kirjas.

independent_work.et: All classes will include a combination of an introductory lecture and a discussion based on the readings. The students are expected to attend all classes, do compulsory readings before each class, and actively take part in discussions.

description.et: EVENT ANALYSIS. This is a small group exercise aimed at identifying an international event (broadly understood, to include both policies and discourses) that, in the opinion of the group, best reflects one of key concepts discussing during the course: change in the international order, patterns of centality and peripherality, regional momentum, security, ethnopolitical and geopolitical dynamics, civilizational identities, the sphere of communication and information, international institutions, and the role of technology, Group members are expected to "unpack" the event, i.e. to explain why it might be considered as representing a certain trend and illustrative of a certain concept. Groups will be asked to present their findings (25 % of the total grade) and then submit a written research note individually (another 25 %).

FORESIGHT ANALYSIS. The gist of this small group assignment is to come up with a scenario - again, related to one of major issues / fields discussed in the class - that would reflect possible developments in the chosen area in a short-run perspective. Scenarios should be developed and articulated by the middle of September by each working group, then discussed among group members in the Moodle (25 % of the total grade), and ultimately presented for class discussions in December (another 25 %).

grade_preconditions.et: In order to get a passing grade for the course, the students must attend at least 60% of all classes, complete all compulsory readings and participate in two small group exercises.

grade_evaluation.et:
Final grade for the course will be based on the following criteria:
Event analysis - 50% (in-class presentation and submission of research note)
Foresight analysis - 50% (Moodle discussion and oral presentation)

debt_elimination.et: By individual agreement with the instructor.

description.et:
International Relations as an academic discipline, its main focal points and debates.
International, trans-/ cross-national and supra-national relations. 
International relations and comparative politics, sociology of international relations, cultural studies and other adjacent fields of research.

Power and politics in international relations.
Politicization and depoliticization as power strategies.

The concept of the world order. From the post-Cold War liberal order to a post-liberal order
Illiberal democracies and populism: repercussions for international politics

Dynamics of center - periphery relations in IR.  Centrality and marginality as analytic vategories.
Borders and international politics.

Region-(un)making in international politics.
The changing patterns of trans-regional integration and disintegration
Geopolitics, ethnopolitics, biopolitics: a conceptual conundrum

Norms and values.
Normativity and norm projection in international relations

Cooperation and conflict. Security and international order.
Case analysis: European and trans-Atlantic security relations and institutions
(Guest lecture by H.E. Ambassador of Germany in Estonia Christoph Eichhorn)
Civilizational approach to international studies. Identities and diasporal trans-nationalism

Communication and information management.
Global media and global connectivity.
Propaganda, disinformation and the "fake news" industry
IT Sector and International Relations: e-technologies and cyber-security
Emotions and performativity in international relations: affective and aesthetic turns in studying IR
Summing Up: Modernity, postmodernity and the future of IR

audience.et: Master students of Johan Skytte institute
